articles.title: A growing number of Nigerian women are upending traditional gender roles and forgoing parenthood
articles.summary: ...urbanisation, rising education levels, and access to digital platforms have given women new scripts. Child freedom, once unthinkable, is quietly gaining momentum.
articles.content:
For Jewel, falling in love isn’t about chemistry. It’s about children. She meets someone, they connect, and they dream out loud together. But once the conversation turns to the future, children, family, and domesticity, the air shifts.

Jewel doesn’t want children. Not now. Not ever. It’s not a temporary phase or the residue of heartbreak; it’s a conscious decision. And in Nigeria, where motherhood is still widely regarded as a woman’s ultimate calling, that decision is radical.

“I just decided to be free,” she says. And by free, she means childfree.

For Jewel, 30, the decision is deeply personal, yet not accidental. As the first daughter in a large family, she practically raised her siblings, nephews, and nieces. That early, prolonged immersion in childcare taught her something important: she loved children, just not enough to become a mother herself. “I love being a doting aunty,” she says. “That’s where it ends for me.”

But endings are rarely accepted when they defy social scripts, and in Nigeria, that script is rigidly linked to marriage, motherhood, and sacrifice. She explains that her decision to be childfree does not stem from pain but from clarity:

Most men think it’s because you’ve been heartbroken or are still healing from some trauma.

That clarity, however, rarely shields her from condescension or outright hostility. She’s been called a “bitter feminist,” told she’ll die alone, and been accused of hating men. In romantic relationships, the backlash is even more acute. She explains:

Two of my most serious relationships ended because the men were convinced I’d change my mind. One of them was married within six months after we broke up.

These encounters speak to a broader tension in Nigerian society: a growing cohort of women is redefining fulfilment, without children, and the persistent pronatalist ideologies that resist change.

In Nigeria, the cultural expectation for women to bear children remains nearly absolute. Motherhood is intertwined with ideas of maturity, morality, and even patriotic duty. A woman who chooses otherwise is not just subverting tradition; to many, she is incomprehensible, yet history complicates this narrative.

Before colonialism, motherhood in many Nigerian communities wasn’t just a private affair; it was also a public institution. Historian Lorelle Semley writes of “public motherhood” in Indigenous societies, where maternal roles extended into the political and economic realms. Women held significant power not only as biological mothers but as community leaders, traders, and spiritual authorities.

That power was systematically eroded under colonial rule. Victorian gender norms, introduced through missionaries and colonial bureaucracy, confined women to domesticity. As Ifi Amadiume outlines in her book “Male Daughters, Female Husbands,” colonialism didn’t just rewrite gender; it redefined womanhood through Christian ideals of submission and self-sacrifice, enforced by church, school, and state.

Today’s childfree women, like Jewel, exist in the long shadow of those historical shifts. But they are also part of a growing countermovement. According to scholar R. Makama, urbanization, rising education levels, and access to digital platforms have given women new scripts. A life without parenthood, once unthinkable, is quietly gaining momentum.

“I am not barren. I just don’t want to have children.”

Oluchi, 26, came to the decision differently. For years, she believed she was simply “not like other girls.” It wasn’t until she discovered online childfree communities that her feelings finally found language. She notes:

There’s a big difference between being barren and being childfree. I am not barren; I just don’t want to have children like [many] women; when I think of my future, they don’t feature in it.

The pushback from her family has been intense, sometimes even cruel. Her mother once told her she hoped for an unplanned pregnancy, “thinking I will change my mind.”

“I keep reiterating to her not to stress me or ask me for a child,” Oluchi says, undeterred. She has grown adept at protecting her peace. “I try to educate when I can, but most times, I just ignore it.”

For Oluchi, this choice is inseparable from feminism. “It gave me the language and the audacity,” she says, emphasising that there’s a direct link where feminism teaches you to question why you want the things you’ve been conditioned to want.

That online support system, mostly on TikTok and X, is informal but invaluable. There’s no Nigeria-specific childfree group, she notes, just a loose but loyal collective of women sharing stories, trading memes, and reminding each other that their choices are valid.

Jewel’s feminism, too, is foundational to her worldview. She grew up reading, questioning, and deciding early on that motherhood was not inevitable. She says:

I knew from the age of eight. And yes, it felt strange at first; being a girl, helping raise siblings. But even then, I knew: this isn’t what I want. It isn’t a compulsory choice, but I have made my choice and stuck with it.

That clarity helped her have honest conversations with her parents. She explains:

My parents grew to respect my decisions because they have lived their lives and have made choices to be parents based on what they wanted for themselves.

Unlike many women, she doesn’t face pressure from her family to get married or bear children, and instead notes, “It’s the men who know your age and shame you for not having a man or child.”

One man she dated claimed to share her ideology, and although she was initially excited, she quickly realized that he had his own selfish agenda. “He didn’t even like women,” she says, revealing that he was a closeted misogynist and incel. Jewel quickly adds that the decision to be childfree can also be difficult for a man. Speaking of one of her male friends who wants to be childfree, “they aren’t firm in their decisions like women because of societal expectations.”

Now, she dates for companionship, not commitment. Jewel notes:

Marriage, however, isn’t my priority, and I have made peace with whether or not I get married. I have siblings, friends and colleagues who are married with two to three children. I am always very happy and supportive [of them].

“When my friends get married, I don’t go around telling women not to have children,” she adds, wishing that she got the same support and respect from people around her.

For Ayanfe, a 25-year-old non-binary Nigerian, the decision to remain childfree came at age 12. The backlash, predictably, came from their family.

My family thinks I am a freak, especially my mom, who still offers prayers each time I tell her I don’t want children.

Jewel’s, Oluchi, and Ayanfe reflect a rising consciousness among Nigerian women and gender-diverse people. For Jewel, this consciousness is linked to reclaiming autonomy and imagining a future where a woman’s worth isn’t tethered to her womb.

Oluchi says:

I think childfree people often have the most respect for children. We know they deserve love and stability…and we refuse to bring them into a life where we can’t promise that.

Jewel agrees. “Every woman has a choice,” she says, reiterating that in a society where womanhood is still defined by marriage and maternity, choosing to be childfree might be the most revolutionary thing a woman can do. “Don’t think [motherhood] is the only path or only way to live your life; there are multiple ways to do so. You own your life and body.”
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a significant social shift in Nigeria where women and gender-diverse individuals are asserting autonomy by choosing to be childfree, challenging entrenched gender roles and pronatalist cultural expectations. This represents meaningful progress in gender equality and personal freedom, with broad societal implications beyond a niche group. The detailed personal stories and historical context provide substantial insight into this evolving movement.
articles.personality_title: More Nigerian women choose to live childfree, challenging old traditions
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In Nigeria, women have traditionally been expected to marry and have children. Motherhood is seen as a key part of being a woman, tied to culture and family values. But this is starting to change for some women and gender-diverse people.

**What happened** – Jewel, Oluchi, and Ayanfe are examples of Nigerians who have chosen not to have children. They say this choice is about freedom and personal clarity, not because of sadness or health problems. They face criticism from family, friends, and partners, but find support through online communities and feminism. Their stories show a growing group questioning old ideas about womanhood and family.

**Impact** – This shift is unique because it challenges deep cultural beliefs in Nigeria, where motherhood is linked to identity and social standing. These women are opening new possibilities for what it means to live a full life without children. Their choices highlight changing views caused by urban living, education, and access to digital spaces where ideas can spread and grow.

**What's next step** – As more Nigerian women speak openly about being childfree, awareness and acceptance may increase slowly. This could lead to more support networks and less pressure to follow traditional paths. The conversation may also influence future generations to think differently about family and personal goals.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A growing number of Nigerian women and gender-diverse people are choosing to be childfree, slowly reshaping cultural expectations about motherhood and womanhood in their society.

articles.personality_title_es: Cada vez más mujeres nigerianas eligen vivir sin hijos, desafiando antiguas tradiciones
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Nigeria, tradicionalmente se espera que las mujeres se casen y tengan hijos. La maternidad se considera una parte clave de ser mujer, ligada a la cultura y los valores familiares. Pero esto está empezando a cambiar para algunas mujeres y personas con diversidad de género.

**Qué pasó** – Jewel, Oluchi y Ayanfe son ejemplos de nigerianas que han decidido no tener hijos. Dicen que esta decisión se basa en la libertad y claridad personal, no en tristeza o problemas de salud. Enfrentan críticas de familiares, amigos y parejas, pero encuentran apoyo en comunidades en línea y el feminismo. Sus historias muestran un grupo creciente que cuestiona las viejas ideas sobre la feminidad y la familia.

**Impacto** – Este cambio es único porque desafía creencias culturales profundas en Nigeria, donde la maternidad está ligada a la identidad y al estatus social. Estas mujeres están abriendo nuevas posibilidades para vivir plenamente sin hijos. Sus elecciones reflejan cambios en las ideas impulsados por la vida urbana, la educación y el acceso a espacios digitales donde las ideas pueden difundirse y crecer.

**Próximo paso** – A medida que más mujeres nigerianas hablan abiertamente sobre vivir sin hijos, la conciencia y aceptación podrían aumentar lentamente. Esto podría llevar a más redes de apoyo y menos presión para seguir caminos tradicionales. La conversación también podría influir en futuras generaciones para pensar diferente sobre la familia y las metas personales.

**Resumen en una frase** – Un número creciente de mujeres y personas con diversidad de género en Nigeria eligen no tener hijos, transformando poco a poco las expectativas culturales sobre la maternidad y la feminidad en su sociedad.

articles.title: The learner drivers using dashcam footage to fight road rage
articles.summary: Learning to drive is a right of passage for many, but drivers and instructors face increasing abuse.
articles.content:
The learner drivers using dashcam footage to fight road rage

3 hours ago Share Save Alex Taylor BBC News reporter, London Share Save

'Give us a bit of room' says learner driver Teddy

"I was so anxious, to the point where my hands and body were shaking. I wanted to park up and just not drive any more." Learner driver Teddy is recounting her fear at being tailgated by another driver mid-lesson. "They followed us, getting up close - shining their lights, even though it was daytime," the 22-year-old tells BBC Morning Live. Getting behind the wheel is a rite of passage for many, but for fledgling drivers like Teddy, it's a challenge that's increasingly being made harder by abuse and intimidation from fellow road users and members of the public. In the UK, all learners must have L plates at the front and rear of their vehicle - so other road users know they are inexperienced. In Wales, D plates are also accepted. Teddy's ordeal only stopped when the driver pulled up to a shop, but the experience knocked her confidence. Yet, rather than give up, Teddy has chosen to keep going. Determined to persevere, she's recently restarted lessons. Morning Live returns on Monday at 0930am. Watch it here. This kind of resilience is necessary for many learning to drive. The average waiting time for a driving test is currently just under six months. Teddy's instructor Debbie says her learners are abused on an almost daily basis. "I'd consider it a good day if I go home and don't recollect any kind of aggressive behaviour towards the learner driver sat next to me," she says.

Teddy restarted driving lessons and hasn't let the intimidation stop her

In a bid to fight back against the intimidation, instructors like Debbie are increasingly installing dashcams to catch instances of abuse. This footage can be vital in securing evidence as inconsiderate driving is an offence - whether it's flashing your headlights, beeping your horn, tailgating or shouting. Over the last five years police forces across the UK have received over 170,000 dashcam clips, according to the National Dashcam Safety Portal. Around 7 out of 10 of those have led to action being taken. And it's not just learner drivers who fall victim to abuse, some cases see instructors made the target. Sonya, from Cheshire, was physically assaulted by another road user last year, when she was taking a pupil on their very first lesson.

The learner temporarily blocked a drive, just as the homeowner returned. Ignoring Sonya's apology, a passenger got out, pulled open her door, and pushed the seatbelt against her neck. The man later threatened to smash the car up with a hammer. Sonya managed to compose herself and finish the lesson, but says she broke down once home. "It was a shock," she says. "I did have more lessons planned that day, but I couldn't do it. I was shaken up." After the incident Sonya bought a new car with doors that lock automatically, and she's now installed dashcams. The man who attacked her was charged and fined £565. PC Richard Woodward, a traffic officer with Cheshire Police for 19 years, says impatience from other road users towards learner drivers and their instructors is growing. He says the police have a number of powers for dealing with aggressive driving and related threatening behaviour.

PC Richard Woodward, a traffic officer with Cheshire Police, says driving convictions typically lead to insurance hikes

This includes Section 59 of the Police Reform Act 2002. On first offence, this allows a warning to be given that stays on an individual's record for the next 12 months. But commit a second similar offence within the year and police have the ability to impound, or take away, vehicles. "And if you do get a driving without due care or inconsiderate driving conviction," says PC Woodward, "typically, insurance companies put your policy up by about 40% each year." Looking ahead, beyond simple fear of the law, Debbie urges people to have more empathy and be kinder on the roads. "Just think about how you felt when it was you [learning to drive]," she says. "And if you can't remember that, then just think about how you would feel if a driver was intimidating someone you loved." Speaking on behalf of learner drivers, Teddy adds: "Don't tailgate. Just give us a bit of room."

Being intimidated? Tips to keep your cool

Getty Images
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a positive social response to the increasing problem of abuse and intimidation faced by learner drivers and instructors. The use of dashcam footage to document and reduce aggressive driving behavior represents a meaningful action with broad societal impact, promoting safer and more respectful road environments. The story focuses on resilience, legal enforcement, and community empathy, providing sufficient context and significance.
articles.personality_title: Learner drivers use dashcams to stand up against road rage
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Learning to drive is an important step for many young people, but learner drivers and their instructors often face rude or aggressive behavior on the road. In the UK, learner drivers must display L plates so others know they are still learning, but this does not always protect them from abuse.

**What happened** – Teddy, a 22-year-old learner driver, shared how she felt scared when another driver tailgated her and flashed headlights during a driving lesson. Her instructor, Debbie, says such aggressive behavior happens almost every day. To fight back, many instructors are using dashcams to record these incidents. The videos help police take action against bad drivers. For example, Sonya, another instructor, was physically attacked during a lesson but used her dashcam to report the attacker, who was fined.

**Impact** – Dashcam footage is proving to be a powerful tool to reduce road rage against learners. Over 170,000 clips have been sent to police in the last five years, with about 70% leading to consequences for offenders. This helps protect learners and instructors, making roads safer and encouraging more people to keep learning despite the challenges.

**What's next step** – Police can warn or fine aggressive drivers, and repeated offenses can lead to their vehicles being taken away. Instructors hope more people will become patient and kind to learner drivers. Teddy and Debbie ask others on the road to give learners extra space and remember how hard learning to drive can be.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Learner drivers and instructors are using dashcam videos to show that road rage is unacceptable and to help create safer, more respectful driving experiences.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les conducteurs débutants utilisent les dashcams pour lutter contre la colère au volant
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Apprendre à conduire est une étape importante pour beaucoup de jeunes, mais les conducteurs débutants et leurs moniteurs font souvent face à des comportements agressifs ou désagréables sur la route. Au Royaume-Uni, les conducteurs débutants doivent afficher des plaques L pour signaler leur statut, mais cela ne les protège pas toujours des abus.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Teddy, une conductrice débutante de 22 ans, a raconté qu’elle avait eu très peur lorsqu’un autre conducteur la suivait de près et lui faisait des appels de phares pendant une leçon de conduite. Sa monitrice, Debbie, explique que ce genre de comportement arrive presque tous les jours. Pour se défendre, beaucoup de moniteurs installent des dashcams pour filmer ces incidents. Ces vidéos aident la police à agir contre les mauvais conducteurs. Par exemple, Sonya, une autre monitrice, a été agressée physiquement pendant une leçon, mais grâce à sa dashcam, l’agresseur a été condamné.

**Impact** – Les vidéos de dashcams sont un outil efficace pour réduire la colère au volant contre les débutants. Plus de 170 000 clips ont été envoyés à la police ces cinq dernières années, et environ 70 % ont mené à des sanctions. Cela protège les conducteurs débutants et leurs moniteurs, rendant les routes plus sûres et encourageant plus de personnes à continuer d’apprendre malgré les difficultés.

**Prochaine étape** – La police peut avertir ou punir les conducteurs agressifs, et en cas de récidive, leurs véhicules peuvent être saisis. Les moniteurs espèrent que les conducteurs seront plus patients et bienveillants envers les débutants. Teddy et Debbie demandent aux autres usagers de laisser plus d’espace et de se souvenir des difficultés rencontrées en apprenant à conduire.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les conducteurs débutants et leurs moniteurs utilisent les vidéos de dashcams pour montrer que la colère au volant est inacceptable et pour favoriser une conduite plus sûre et respectueuse.
articles.personality_title_es: Los conductores novatos usan cámaras para enfrentar la agresión en las carreteras
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Aprender a conducir es un paso importante para muchos jóvenes, pero los conductores novatos y sus instructores a menudo enfrentan comportamientos groseros o agresivos en la carretera. En el Reino Unido, los aprendices deben mostrar placas L para indicar que están aprendiendo, pero esto no siempre los protege del abuso.

**Qué pasó** – Teddy, una conductora novata de 22 años, contó que se asustó mucho cuando otro conductor la seguía muy de cerca y le hacía señales con las luces durante una clase de manejo. Su instructora, Debbie, dice que este tipo de comportamiento ocurre casi todos los días. Para defenderse, muchos instructores están usando cámaras de tablero para grabar estos incidentes. Los videos ayudan a la policía a tomar medidas contra los conductores agresivos. Por ejemplo, Sonya, otra instructora, fue atacada físicamente durante una clase, pero con su cámara pudo denunciar al agresor, que fue multado.

**Impacto** – Las grabaciones de las cámaras están demostrando ser una herramienta fuerte para reducir la agresión contra los aprendices. En los últimos cinco años, se han enviado más de 170,000 videos a la policía, y cerca del 70% han resultado en acciones contra los infractores. Esto ayuda a proteger a los aprendices y a los instructores, haciendo las carreteras más seguras y motivando a más personas a seguir aprendiendo a pesar de los retos.

**Próximo paso** – La policía puede advertir o multar a los conductores agresivos, y si repiten la falta, pueden quitarles el vehículo. Los instructores esperan que más personas sean pacientes y amables con los conductores novatos. Teddy y Debbie piden a los demás conductores que den más espacio y recuerden lo difícil que es aprender a conducir.

**Frase resumen** – Los conductores novatos y sus instructores usan videos de dashcam para demostrar que la agresión en la carretera no es aceptable y para ayudar a crear una experiencia de manejo más segura y respetuosa.
